definition:
A metric space $X$ is [*complete*]{} if every in $X$ is a convergent
sequence.

[**Examples:**]{}

-   The space $\mathbb{Q}$ of rational numbers is not complete: the
    sequence $3$, $3.1$, $3.14$, $3.141$, $3.1415$, $3.14159$,
    $3.141592\ldots$ consisting of finite decimals converging to
    $\pi \in \mathbb{R}$ is a Cauchy sequence in $\mathbb{Q}$ that does
    not converge in $\mathbb{Q}$.

-   The space $\mathbb{R}$ of real numbers is complete, as it is the
    completion of $\mathbb{Q}$ with respect to the standard metric
    (other completions, such as the $p$-adic numbers, are also
    possible). More generally, the completion of any metric space is a
    complete metric space.

-   Every Banach space is complete. For example, the $L^p$–space of
    p-integrable functions is a complete metric space if $p \geq 1$.
